definition:
**Differential logic** is the component of logic whose object is the
description of variation — for example, the aspects of change,
difference, , and diversity — in universes of discourse that are subject
to logical description. In formal logic, differential logic treats the
principles that govern the use of a **differential logical calculus**,
that is, a formal system with the expressive capacity to describe change
and diversity in logical universes of discourse.

A simple example of a differential logical calculus is furnished by a .
This extends an ordinary in the same way that extends analytic geometry.
